lines: You are having some very important guests over for dinner, and you would like everything to be "just so."
#SEND OUT FOR DINNER / HIRE A CATERER
#SEND OUT FOR DINNER / HIRE A CATERER
You realize that preparing the correct kind of hors d' oeuvre can set the tone for the entire meal.
You labor over some exotic hors d'oeuvres that bring rave reviews from your guests, who marvel at your culinary talents.
Mrs. Andrews says, "My, My. I don't understand where you get your energy. You do such a fine job with cooking and you work during the day as well. You should be very proud of yourself."
Relieved that the first part of the evening has gone along so smoothly, you rush into the kitchen to bring out the main course.
You are horrified to realize that with all of the attentiion you have given to the hors d' oeuvres, you completely forgot to begin preparing the main course!
#CALL OUT FOR FOOD/HIDE IT FROM YOUR GUESTS
The only thing open that will deliver is a southern fried chicken establishment which prepares everything in a greasy gravy. Do you want to order some?
Your guests eat the chicken but can't understand the discrepency between the two courses. They assume you called out for the appetizers. Your furniture gets grease stains all over it.

You are amazed to see how understanding your guests are. One person offers to go out for Chinese food. Another runs to the all-night deli and rustles up some vegetable salads and dessert. Sometimes a gaffe such as the one you made makes
people tune in to their own frailties. Everyone has a great time. Social sphere increases.
The cheese and crackers are a flop, and so is the dinner!
The guests enjoy the food. They think that it was practical for you to hire a caterer, because you work so hard during the day. The evening is a moderate social success.
The guests gossip about the fact that you do not work, yet you spend your husband's money on catering when you have guests over. They enjoy the meal, but socially you are a flop.
